metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: With Pyplot, you can use the xlabel() and ylabel() functions to set a label for the x- and y-axis.
content.html: With Pyplot, you can use the xlabel() and ylabel() functions to set a label for the x- and y-axis.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = np.array([80, 
  85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 
  270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])plt.plot(x, y)plt.xlabel("Average 
  Pulse")plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")plt.show()

content.code_html:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = np.array([80, 85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])
y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])

plt.plot(x, y)

plt.xlabel("Average Pulse")
plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")

plt.show()

content.text: Create a Title for a Plot
With Pyplot, you can use the title() function to set a title for the plot.
content.html: With Pyplot, you can use the title() function to set a title for the plot.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = np.array([80, 
  85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 
  270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])plt.plot(x, y)plt.title("Sports Watch Data")plt.xlabel("Average 
  Pulse")plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")plt.show()

Pulse")plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

content.text: Set Font Properties for Title and Labels
You can use the fontdict parameter in xlabel() , ylabel() , and title() to set font properties for the title and labels.
content.html: You can use the fontdict parameter in xlabel(), ylabel(), and title() to set font properties for the title and labels.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = np.array([80, 
  85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 
  270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])font1 = {'family':'serif','color':'blue','size':20}
  font2 = {'family':'serif','color':'darkred','size':15}plt.title("Sports 
  Watch Data", fontdict = font1)plt.xlabel("Average Pulse", fontdict = 
  font2)plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage", fontdict = font2)plt.plot(x, 
  y)plt.show()

content.code:
import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = np.array([80,
85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260,
270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])font1 = {'family':'serif','color':'blue','size':20}
font2 = {'family':'serif','color':'darkred','size':15}plt.title("Sports
Watch Data", fontdict = font1)plt.xlabel("Average Pulse", fontdict =
font2)plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage", fontdict = font2)plt.plot(x,
y)plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = np.array([80, 
 85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 
 270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])font1 = {'family':'serif','color':'blue','size':20}
  font2 = {'family':'serif','color':'darkred','size':15}plt.title("Sports 
  Watch Data", fontdict = font1)plt.xlabel("Average Pulse", fontdict = 
  font2)plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage", fontdict = font2)plt.plot(x, 
  y)plt.show()

content.code_html:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = np.array([80, 85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])
y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])

font1 = {'family':'serif','color':'blue','size':20}
font2 = {'family':'serif','color':'darkred','size':15}

plt.title("Sports Watch Data", fontdict = font1)
plt.xlabel("Average Pulse", fontdict = font2)
plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage", fontdict = font2)

plt.plot(x, y)
plt.show()

  font2 = {'family':'serif','color':'darkred','size':15}plt.title("Sports 
  Watch Data", fontdict = font1)plt.xlabel("Average Pulse", fontdict = 
  font2)plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage", fontdict = font2)plt.plot(x, 
  y)plt.show()

content.text: You can use the loc parameter in title() to position the title.
content.html: You can use the loc parameter in title() to position the title.

content.text: Legal values are: 'left', 'right', and 'center'. Default value is 'center'.
content.html: Legal values are: 'left', 'right', and 'center'. Default value is 'center'.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = np.array([80, 
  85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 
  270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])plt.title("Sports Watch Data", loc = 'left')plt.xlabel("Average 
  Pulse")plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")plt.plot(x, 
  y)plt.show()

content.code_html:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = np.array([80, 85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])
y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])

plt.title("Sports Watch Data", loc = 'left')
plt.xlabel("Average Pulse")
plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")

plt.plot(x, y)
plt.show()
